Little Sihcrhair while planing w At fen St, hearing some strange mutie in the distance, follows the sound till the finds herself ammufst
the fairies mho ftati her u-ilh dtinties, awl with whom she sports and dances till the dawn of morning. The cause of th s kindness em the
mri\ of the fairies is owing to their term of exiitena being at an end, if they fail to procure as a guest, thrift their last midnight hour, some
vounqandfloodgiri. Little Sitverhmr, hauing become this guest and the means of prolonging the lives of the fames for another century, returns
home quite changed in hrr nature, and tilth a. strange disposition to touch and to meddle with event thing she sees. The Squire of the place, m.
U'AicA the resides teith her mother, court* her with presents, and she snatches them from him. Htr loner returns home from sea, and offers t»
thare his prize-money with her, but she snatches U all cml af his hand, and again runs into the forest, where the first thing she sees is the home
t>f the Three Bears, uiho have gone out tor a um'k while the. hot porridge, which then havprepared for breakfast, gets cool. Little Silrerhair
enters the house and MKM three porr-d.ie-pole with porridge all hot iv tb-rn, tastes every one, and empties the last. Then she tits in the three
chaiv belonging to the. hears, till she .•,,- tie bottom of one ofthtm out. Then falling sleepy through being nith the fairies all night, she qoet

the fairies, who feast her with dainties, and aith whom the sports and Janets till the dawn of morning. The amuse tf th I kiniteti on the
part of 'he fairies is owing to their term of existent* being at an end, if they fail to procure at a guest, during their last midnight hour, some
ng and good firi.
Little Silrerhair, havinq become this guest and the means of prolonging the lives of the fairies for another century, return*
te quite thonged in her nature, and with a strange disposition tt touch and to meddle with every thing she seel. The Squire of the place, i tenth she resides with her mother, courts her with presents, and she snatches them from him, Hsr Icier returns home from lea, and offers (#
.ti>r' hisprite-money with her, but the snatches it all out of h\t hand, and again runs into the forest, where the first thing the tee' it the house
mfthe Three Sears, mho hate gone out tor a wa'h while the hot porridge, -Aid. they hate prepared for breakfast, gels tool. Lttttt Silver hair
enter the hoeite, and iseinq three porridge-pott ivilh porridge all hot in them, tastet every one, and empties the last. Then she tils m the three
tnaii i belonging to the bears, till she sits the bottom, of one of th»m out. Then falling sleepy through being with the fairies all night, she goes
up slain to find a bed to lav donrn upon, when she sees three hds: she lies aonm tspon all of them, andfalh fast asleep upon one. Them
home con,, the three bears —they fitt'f the porridge has been tasted and on. of the pots emptied; they find the chairs hate teen meddled with, and
ynr of them with the bottom broken through ; they then search for the intruder, and find her fait asleep in the bed. '• S o m e b o d y t t f t .
b e e n l y i n g i n m y b e d 'exclaims the smallest of the behri^ " a n d h e r e S h e i . . " Si.eer'.air then wakes up in a fright, and seeing
the bears, e..c.*ayo.r., to escape from th -m, but they /atch her, i\nd being about to cut off her head, she begs a boon and which is, that they wtm
give hn a hammer and a long nail before she dies. The simple bears agree to this, when she immediately nails all their three tails to the floor %
and is about to escape by the window, whm the bears break atrtaff team their fastening, and agam pursue her; but the Queen of the fairiet, low
being her friend, suddenly appears, and at Silverkair has been foUomed to the house by her lover, her mother, the Squirt and his m-im^she Jrairf,
mfier thinking the matter over, changes the littte girl's lover to Imftcquin, the little girl herself a beautiful Columbine, the Squire ins* e>UUah>oll^

young and good j/iri. Little Sikerhair, kantng hecome this guest and me means of prolonging the Uses of the fairies for another century, returns
home quite changed in her nature, and with a ttrante disposition to touch, and to meddle milk event thing she sees. The Squire of the place, in
which she resides with her mother, courts her with presents, and she snatehes then from him. Htr lover returns home from sea, and offers Us
thare hisprize-money with her, but she snatches it all out of his hand, and again runs into the forest, where the first thing she tees it the house
of the Three Bears, who have gone out for a wa'k while the hot portdge, which they have prepared for breakfast, gets cool. Little Silverhair
enter the houte, and seeing three porridge-pott with porridge all hot in them, tastes every one, and empties the last. Then she tils m the three
rhaiv, belonging to the bears, till she sits the bottom of one of them out. Then falling sleepy through being with the fairies all night, she gate
up stair' to find a bed to lay damn upon, when she sees three beds ; she lies down upon all of them, and fal't fast asleep upon one. Then
home come the three bears—thug find the porridge has been tatted and one of the pots emptied; they find the chairs have been meddled with, and'
one of them with the bottom broken (nrau^n. they then tearcti for the intruder, and find her fan" asleep in the bed. ' S o m e b o d y tea.

young and good giri. tattle Sitvnhair, hating become this guest tend the means of prolonging the lives of the fairies for another eeniary, returns
M l quite changed in her nature, and with a ttrange disposition to touch and to meddle with M,tf thing she sees. The Squire of the place, m
mhieh she resides with her mother, (-art) her with prctenti, and she snatches them from him. Htr lover return? home from sea, and offers It
.Ian hisprize-moneg with her, but she snatches it all out of his hand, and again runs into the forest, where the first thing %he tees t» the house
of the Three Bears who luive 170.11: out Inr a am 'k while the hot porridge, which they have prepared for brtahfalt, gits cool. Little Sifrterhoir
tnter the houte, and see.ina three porridge-pots with porridge nit hot in them, tastet even) one, and empties the last. Then she tnts in the three
—•%. belonging to the bears, till she. silt the bottom, of one of them out. Then falling sleepy through being with the fairies alt night, sit goet
tip Matr* (o find a bed to Iny dotr-n upon, when she sees three beds; she lies Aemn upon all of them, and falls fast asleep upon one. Then
home come the three bear'—they find the porridge has been tasted and one of the pots emptied ; they find the chairs have been reddled with, anet
one of them with the bottom brnkm through . they then search for the intruder, and find her last asleep in the bed. '• S o m e b o d y h a .
b e . n l y i n g i n m y b e d . ' exclaim* the smallest of the bears, " a n d h « r . s h e i l . " Siherhatr then wakes up in a fright, and seeing
the heart, endeavours to escape, from'.I'm, but they tatthfor,and being about to cut off her head, she begs a boon and which is. that they mm
ffime her a hammer and a long nail befnr: she dies. The simple hears agree to thie, when she immediately nails all their three tails la thc/toor;
and is about to escape by the umdnm, whin the bears break airmy taom their fastening, and again pursue htr ; but the Queen of the Fairies, nam
fmng her friend, suddenly appears, ord'is Hilwrhair has been followed to the hou'si by her lover, ker mother, the Squire nnd ku mtin,the Fairy,
after thinking the matter over, changes the little girl'H lover to Harlequin, the little girl herself a beautiful Columbine, lb; Squire into Pantaloon
and hu man into Clown, so that after a time Sifoerhair may recover her natural disposition, be married to her four, and live happy ever after.

tM.Lt Silverhair, u hilt plating m the forest, hearing some strange music in the dittav.ce, follows the sound tiU th* finds herielf amongst
the fairies, mho feat' her with dain'ts, ani with whom she sports arid dances till the dawn of morning. The cause etfth s kindness on the
marl of the fairies i, o*.rJM (o their term of existent) being at an end, if the;/ fail to procure as a guest, during their last midnight ho>tr, stmt
young and good airi. Little Silverhah, having become this guest and the means of prolonging the lives ofthe fairies for another Centura, returns
home quite ckanaed in her nature, and with a strange disposition to touch and to meddte with event thing she sees. The Squire of the place, in
which she resides with her mother, court- her witk presents,and sht snatches them from him. Htr lover returns home from sea, and offers la
Shore hisprize-money with her, but she snatches it all out of his hand, and again runs into the forest, where the first thing nhe sect u the house
ttf the Three Bears, who have gone out for a wa'k tehilc the hot porridge, which they have prepared for breakfast, gets cool. I.tttte Si.'verhair
enter the house, and seeing three porridge-pots with porridge all hot in them, tastes every one, and empties the last. Then she sits in the three
thaivs belanging'ti) the bears. Hit she sits the bottom of one of them out. Then filling tleepy through being with the fairies all night, she asset
wt> stairs to find a bed to lay doner* upon, when she sees three beds; she lies dorm* upon all of litem, and faVs fast asleep upon one. Tlien
mome come the three bears—they find the porridge has been tasted and one of the pots emptied; they find the chairs have been meddled with, atiff
one of them with the bottom broken through : they then search for the intruder, and find her fast asleep in the bed. " S o m e b o d y h a s
b o . n l y i n g i n m y b e d . ' exclaim the smallest of the bears, *' a n d h e r e 8 h . i . . " Silveihair then wakes up in a fright, andsctina
the bears, endeavours to escape from ihttn, but they catch her, and being about to cut off her head, she begs a boon and which is, that they utw.
give her a hammer and a long vail before she dies. The simple bears agree to this, when she immediately nails all their three tails to the <ioor •
and is about to escape by the li-indam, when the bears break arcaftanm their fastening, and again pursue her ; but the Queen of the Paints, now
heing her friend, suddenly appears, and as SUverkair has been followed to the houst bf her lewer, her mother, the Squirt and kis man, the Fair*,
after thinking tht mott'r'over, changes iht little girl's lover to fhrlegain, the tittle girl kerselfa. beautiful Columbine, tht Squire inta Pantaloati
said his man into Clnvn, so that after a time Silverhair may recover her natural disposition, be married to her later, and live happy ever after.

Little SUverhalr

WU

*>

The ftueen of England, in her Yacht " The Fairy.*;

£«'«,.. Silverlair, white planing in the forest, hearing some strange music in the distance, follows the sound till she findt herself amongst
the fairies, who feast her with dainties, awl with whom she sports and dances till the dawn of morning. The cause efths kindness on the
perl of the fairies is owing to their term of existence being at an end, if they fail to procure at a guest, during their last midnight hour, same
voung and good gin. Little Siherhair, having become this guest and the means of prolonging the lives of the fairies for another century, return*
home quite changed in her nature, and n-ith a ttlange disposition to touch and to meddle with evert/ thing she sees. The Squire, of the place, in
which she resides mth her mother, courts her with presents, and she snatches them from. him. Htr lover returns home from sea, and offers in
thin hisprize-mon'y xvith her, hut she snatches it alt out of his hand, and again runs into the forest, vthere the first thing she sees is the house
tfthe Three Bears, who hare gone out for a wn'k white the hot porridge, which they have prepared for breakfast, gets cool. Little Silverhair
enters the house, and seeing three porndge-pots with p-rrridge all hot in them, tastes every one, and empties the last. Then she sitsrathe three
thaivs belonging to the hews, till she tits the bottom of one of them out. Then falling sleepy through being with the fairies all night, she qaet
*p stairs tofinil a bed to lay doirn upon, when she sees three beds ; she lies doien upon all of them, and fat's fast asleep upon one. Tken-,
home come the three bears~they find the po-ridye has been tast'd and one of the pots emptied; they find tht chairs have been meddled with, aiuT'
tme of them with the bottom broken through ; they then search for the intruder, and find her fast asleep in the bed. •• S o m e b o d y h . M
b e e n l y i n g i n HIT b e d , ' ttclams the smallest of the heart, " a n d h e r . S h e t S . " Silverhair then wakes up in a fright, and seeina
the bears, endeavours to escape from them, but they . atch her, and being about to cut of her head, she begs a boon and which is, that they will
e/ive her a hammer anil a long rail before she dies 7Vi» simple bears agree to this, when she immediately nails all their three tails to thefiaor}
and is about to escape by the ivindort, when the bean Weak array loom their fastening, and again pursue her ; but the Queen of the Fairies, nolo
being her friend, mdde dy appears, and as Silwrkas- has been followed to the house by her lover, her mother, the. Squire and his man, the Fan",,'
after thinking the matter over, changes tht lime girl'i lover to Uarlequin, the little girl herself a beautiful Columbine, the Squire int» Pantaloon,
mnd his man into Clown, ,-.. that after , t ".» Siherhair may recover her natural disposition, be marriedtoher Imtr, and live happy ever after.
The Scener. if the Opening of the Pantomime and the concluding Scene, painted by

the fairies, who frill her wilh daintiet, and with wham At sport* and dances till the damn of momma. The cause of this kininest an the
mart af the fairies is owtnj to their term of exiitenm being at an end, if they failtoprocure at a guest, during their Ian midnight hour, tame
young and good firl. little Siherhair, .rank), become this guest taut Ac meant ofprolonging the Uvea of the fairies for another century, return*
tame quite changed in her nature, and Kith a Mange disposition to touch and to meddle with retry thing the seel. The Squire of the place, m
which the resides aith her mot".*-, courts her with present!, and she snatches them from him. Hfr lover returns home from sea, and afers la
atare his prize-money with her, but she snatches it all out af his hand, and again runs into the forest, where the frit thine, the tees it the house
of the Three Bears, who hate gone out for a wa'k while tie hot porridge, which they have prepared for breahfatt, gets cool. Little Silterhair
enters the house and v.einq three porrtdqe.pots uith porridge all hot in them, taste* every one, and emptier the last. Then she sits m the three
chairs belonging to the bears, till she sits the b->thm of one of them ant. Then falling sleepy through being with the fairies all ntght, she goel
€B stairs tofinda bed to lie doren upon, whan 'he sees three beds: she IKS dimn up"n all of them, and falls fast asleep upon one. Then
%ome come the. three bears—theffindthe porridge has been tasted and one of the pots emptied; thenfindthe chairs hare been meddled with, and
one oflhmn with the bottom broken thrmmh : they then search for the intruder, and find her fast asleep in the bed. ' S o m e b o d y tUUS
b e e n l y i n g i n m y b e d . ' .-soM-M •*» smallest of the bran, " a n d h . r e S h . l».'* Silverhatr then wakei up in a fright, and seeing
Sfi heart, endem:vtrstoencap* from them, hut theg eatch her, and being about to cut off her head, she begs a (won and uhich is, that they wilF
mine her a hammer and a long nail befor- she dies. The simple bean agree to this, when sht immediately nails all their three tails to the floor f.
omd is about to escape by the windoo, tchen the bears break array foam their fastening, and again purine H*r; out the Queen of the Fairies, nam
firing her frvnd, suddenly appears, and as Silverkatr has been followed to the house by her lover, her mother, the Squire and his man, the Fairfr
mfter th'nkmg the matter ortr, changes the tittle jWi lover to tiarkqtfU, the little girl herself to a beautiful Columbine, tht Squire i.v. Pantaloon.

MlsHALLERinthePiayofTHB

Lille Silverl.air, while playing in the fort*!, heating some strange music in the distance, follow the sound till eh' find) herself amongi'
ike fairies, who feast her with d-miies, and with whom the sport* and dances till the dawn of morning. The cause of this kin bins an the
part of the fairies is tying to their term of existence being ut an end, if they fail to procure a» a guest, daring their last midnujht lunir, some
fjeung and good girl. Utile Silverhair, hating become this guest and the mains of prolonging the lives of the fairi?s fur another etntorv, returns
home quite changed in her n U P i and with a strange disposition to touch and to meddle with every thing she sees. The. ttftWrt of the place, in
which she resides with her mother, court.-, her with presents, and she snatches them from him. Htr lover returns home from sea. and offers to
Share his pf he-money with her, bv> she snntahss it all out of his fraud, and again runs into the forest, where the first thing the sees is the house
of the Three Bears, who hare gone out lot a~ wa h while the hot porridge, which thru "tore prepared for breakfast, gets coil. I utle Stlverhait
enters the house, and teeing three porridge-pots with porridge all hot in them, tastes evert/ one, and etnptus the last. Then the sits in the three
tkairs belonging to the bears, till 'he sits the bottom, pf one of them out. Then falling sleepy through being with the fairies all night, -he goes
up stair' to find n bed to lie down upon, when she sees three beds; .'he lis down upon all of them, and falls fast arteep upon t «»
Then
home come the three heart—they find the porridge has been tailed and me of the pots emptied ; they find the chairs have betn meddler! : nh, mi'
one of them with the bottom brokn through I then then search for the intruder, and find her fart asleep M the bed. " S o m e b o d y a t . ,
b e a n l y i n g i& m y b e d ' «twfa-»J the smallest of the bears. " a n d b . r . S f t . a V * Sihorhenr then wakes up in a fright , :d leeiiw
the bears, endeavours to escape from them, lint they latch her, and Wing about to cut off her head, the begs a boon and whichft,t>.. tl- • vsifl
tjive her a hammer and a long nail befon she dies. The simple bears agree to this, when she immediately nail* till their three tails 10 th Hoar ;
•no" is about to escape by the ivindnu, wlkf. the bears break array faom their fastening, and again pursue her ; but the Queen of f% Pat-'es. note
Using her friend, suddenly appe set, and at Sllverkair has been follorced to the house o , her lover, hermother, the Squire and kit m , . , tlte&'<ur0t
afiet thinking the matter over, changes the little girl's later to Harlequin, the little girt herself to n beautiful Columbine, the Squire into Pintakow,
send hit man into Clown, so thtt after a time Sttrerhair may recover her natural disposition, b' married to her loser, and live happy torn after.

fWlth t h e

LABY of LYONS

M.GXS17.
Litte Sihereair, white p/ovi.o tt •-.« forts!, hearing some strange mitlic ,« the distance, follows the sound till she find* herself amongst
the fairies, who feast her with dainties, and with whom she sports and dances till the dawn of morning. The cause of this kindness on the
part of the fairies is m m to their term nf existenra being at an end, if they fail to procure as a guest, during their last midnight hour, same
young and good girl. Little Sikeihair, harina become this guest and the means of prolonging the lives of the-fairies for another century, return,
tome quite changed in her nature, and n-ilh a strange disposition to touch and to meddle with event thing she sees. The Squire of the place, in
which she resides with her mother, court* her with presents, and she snatches them from hint. Hir lover returns home from sea, and offers to
«fer? his prize-money with her, bv) she matches it all out of his hand, and again runs into the forest, where the first thing Sfte sees it the house
of the Three Bears, who hove gone out tor a wa'k while the hot porridge, which they have prepared for breakfast, gets cool. Little Stlverhair
enters the house, and seeing three porridye-pots with porridge all hot in them, tastes every one, and empties the last. Then she sits in the three
tkairs belonging to the bears, till she sits the bottom of one of them out. Then falling sleepy through being with the fairies all night, she goes
m stairs to find o bed to lie don-n upon, when she sees three beds; she lies down upon all of them, and falls fast asleep upon one. Then
home come the three bears—they find the porridge has been tailed and one of the pots emptied ; they find the chairs have been meddled urith, and"
erne of them with the bottom broken through; then then search for the inlmder, and find her last asleep in the bed. ' S o m e b o d y h a s
b e e n l y i n g i n m y b e d . ' exclaims the smallest of the bears, ** a n d h e r . S h e 1»." Silverhair then wakes up in a fright, and seeing
the heart, endeavou. s to escape from them, hut they catch her, and being about to cut off her head, she begs a boon and which is. that thai will'
five her a hamtSUr and a long nail be for-: she dies. The simple bears ague to this, when she immediately nails all their three tails to the floor;
and is about to escape bit the windati. wlun the bears break ureal/ loom their fastening, and again pursue h>r ; but tlie Queen of the Fames, now
beinq her friend, suddenly appears, and as Silrcrhair has been foil on-ed to the houti by her lover, her mother, the Squire and'his man, the Fairs)Y
after thinking the matter over, changes the little girl's lover to Harlequin, the little girl herself to a beautiful. Columbine, the Squire into Pantaloon,
and his man into Clown, so that after a tins Silvirhair may recover he/ natural disposition, be married la her later, and live happy ever after.

Lilt e Si'terlair, while plaiting in the /oris., heaimg tome strange music it. the distance, follcunt the sound tut she finds hetse.j —Hunt
the fairies, who frost her with daintiet, and with whom the sports and donees till the dawn of morning. J he canst of this kindness on the
part of the fatties is owing to their trim of existence being at an end, if they fait to procure a* a guest, during their last midnight hour, same
tung and good girl. Little Stlverhmr, having become this guest and the means of prolonging the lives of the fairies for another eenturt/, returns
*me quite changed in her nature, and with a ttrange disposition to touch and to meddle with every thing the sen. The Sautre of the place, m
tthich she resides mth her mother, courts her with presents, and she snatches them from him. Ilir lover returns home from tern, and offers tr
lhare his prize-money with her, hit she snatches it all out of his hand, a~d again runs into the forest, where the first thing the sees it the house
t/fthe Three Bears, who hate gone out for a wa'k while the hot porridge, which they have prepared /or breakfast, gets cool. Little Siherhair
titters the house, and seeing three pomdae-pots with porridge all hot in them, tastes every one, and empties the last. Then she sits in the three
thairs belonging to the bears, till she sits the. bottom of one of them out. Then falling sleepy through betng with the fairies all night, 'htjpet
«p stain tofind a bed to lie down upon, when she sees three beds; she lies down upon all of them, and fal's fast asleep upon one. Thus
home come the three bears—then furl the porridge has been tailed and one of the pots emptied: they find the chain hare been meddled with, and
me of them wtth the bottom broken through ; they' then search for the intruder, and find her last asleep in the bed. '• S o m e b o d y -JA3
b e e n l y i n g i n m y b « d . ' exclaims the smallest of the bears, " a r i d h e r e S h e if.'" SUverhatr then wakes up in a fright, aniserhui
the h'art, endeavours to en ape from them, but they latch her, and being about to cut off her head, she begs a koan and which is. that then ttlt
five h-r a hammer and a long nail before she dies. The simple hears agree to thit, when she immediately nails all their three tails to thefloor;
tmd is ahoul to escape by the windotn, ich'n the bears break away faom there fastening, and again pursue her , but the Queen of the Fairiet, MO—
being her friend, suddenly appears, and at Silterkatr hat been followed tothe housi by her
lmcr,inmtsthtr,lheSquirtandkuman,tkeFutrfl,
after thinking the matter'orer, changes the littte girl's lover to Harlequin, the little girl herself to a beautiful Columbine, the Sguire into Pantaloon.
and hit man into Clown, so that after a time Silvtrhair may reenter her natural disposition, be married to Her loter, and lire happy ever after.

. .!'' A , ' , " ' ' < " r , white playing in the forest, hearing some strange music in the distance, fallcm the sound tut the finds hei My amongtt
the fainet, who featt ACTwith dainties, and with whom she sportt and dances till the daunt of morning. The cause of this kindnett im the
part of the fairies is owing to their term of rzistenct being at an end, if ,/iei/ fail to procure at a guest, during their last midnight hour, tone
fjoung and good girl. Little Siherhair, liatinabenme this truest and the means of prolonging the lives of the fairies for another centim/, returns
tome quite changed in her nature, rmd with a strai ge disposition to touch and to meddle with event thing she sees. The Squire of the place, in
which she resides aith her mother, courts her with presents, and she snatches them from him. rfir lover returns home from sea, and offers «
«*-*" huprhe-monev with her, hut \hc snatches it all out of his hand, and again rims into the forest, where the first thing the sees it the house
erf the Three Bears, who have gone out for n ira'k while the hot porridge, which thesi hare prepared for breakfast, gets cool. Little Siherhair
testers the houee, and seeing ilwee porridge-pott with porridge all hot in them, tastes event one, and empties the last. Then she tits in the three
chairs belonging to the bears, till she lit) the luilnm of one of them out. Then falling sleepy through being with the fairies ail night, she qoet
Up Hairs to find a bed to lie damn upon, when the sees three beds; she lies down upon all of them, and fal't fast asleep upon one.
then
home come the three bears—they find the porridge has been tatted and 'me of the pots emptied; they find the chairs hare been meddled with, and,
etna of them with the bottom broken through ; they then tearch for the intruder, and find her last asleep in the bed. " S o m e b o d y h a .
T.J#.n l y i n g i n m y b e d , ' exclaims the smallest of the bear's, " a n d h e r e S h e l a . " Siherhair then wakes up in a fright, and seeing
the bean, endeavours to escape from them, hut they catch her, and being about to cut off her head, she begs a boon and which isi that they unit
five her a hummer and a long nail before she dies. The simple bears agree to this, when she immediately nails all their three tails to the floor;
and it about to escape, by the windem, when the btart break array taom their fastening, and again pursue her; but the Queen of the Fairiei.nont
being her friend, suddenly appears, and at Sthcrkair has been followed to the house by her lover, her mother, the Squire and hit m o . , the Fain
mfitr thinking the matter over, changes the tuUc girl's lover to H'arlequin, the little girl herself to a beautiful Columbine, the Squire into Pantalo '
and hi* man into Clown, so that after a time Siherhair may recover her natural disposition, be married to her lot er, and live happy ever after

all the Original Music by Sir H. BISHOP) continues to be received with entnusiasm.

•v •• » n • • &
In presenting this Doleful Trigeuy for the first time on the Stage of
nny Theatre, it is believed that a few particulars relative to its literary
history will neither prove unimportant, or uninteresting. The play
itself, which has been recently discovered amongst the papers of a retired
Cheesemonger, belongs apparently to the Elizabethan period, a supposition rendered more probable by a Latin inscription on the fly-leaf which,
though nearly obliterated by time, may be decyphered thus.—-- MiM
Bt Hetti ..Vfartinf," signifying doubtless the names of the joint
Authors as "Myself and Elizabeth Martin;" names which though not
familiar, perhaps, to the students of our early dramatic history, are yet
of no .rare occurrence in popular literature. As the most mdefat^hls
researches in the British Museum have failed to bring to light any quarto
or folio edition of '• Ye Tragioalle Hystorie of Willikind and his Dinah,
with ye manner of theyre love-makynge, ye Cruelie Parient's enautie,
and theyre most pittiful ends," there is reason to believe that it wa
never printed, and, consequently, it is fair to sssume, that it was never
published. The original story on which the plot was based seems equally
to have baffled the investigation of those who sought to trace the legend
to its primitive source, An anonymous writer in a work dated 1583, and

W I T H N E W S C E N E R Y . DRE.SSKS a n d D E C O R A T I O N S ,

ntitled " A Paradise of Curious Conceits a n d
D o i n t i e D e v i c e s * ' ' alludes to a similar story in which a Paren1'
refuses consent to a Daughter's Marriage. The name of Williklnd, however, seems unknown in the Parish Registers before 1802, when it figures ji
in an entry, which would seem to show that a person of that name then
existed, but whether it was the same individual-there is now no possible
method of ascertaining—Dinah, or Dianah - the interjection "ah!" having
been palpably appended to the first syllable to express the melancholy
nature of her career,—has been often made the subjeot of reference by
the lyrists of Ethiopia, but there is no reason for supposing tnat they
could throw any light on the present history. Under these oircunt
stances, as it wonld appear that no information can be gained by pursuing the inquiry any further it seems to be most advisable to desist
from the attempt, and the curious in these etymological, genealogical
and archaeological researches are, therefore, confidently referred to the
Tragedy itseli, which will he found to embrace ail the jmrUeulars hitherto *

Ciown and Pantaloon..Clown and Pantaloon's own Engine and Tender

Little BO'pecp was a pretty $h*/Atrdttt, residing in that beautiful pin''- called Arcadia. She was a very good girl, but had one fault; and
thatwat, she would often fall nsleip in fA« day time, when she emyht to hare been lending her sheep. Her godmother, who mas a Fairy. wot eery
ttngry with her, and tried to coned her, but in rain ; till one day a Waif, who lived in a c arern near this beautiful plact, hawing fallen in loot
With Bo-peep and been rejected by her, • vt of revenge, resolved to steal her shie.p, cut iff their tails, and hang them up on a tree to dry. Bo-peep,
al usual, having fallen asleep, rendered the stealing her flock a very easy matter for the Waif and hit companions. While she was sleeping, her
(jtebnothcr showed to her, in a dream, the lonseqneme* of laziness . and then there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesses who wereliving Stud playing and dancing in a grove of laburnums, and were happy as the days were long, because in their time they had never been idlo. When,
&»-ptep woke out of this dream, she found ho sheep had been taken away, so she set out determined for to find them : when going along what should
ikt see, but the tails of all her poor sheep »i.:.i,,g up, side by side, on a tree to dry ' She then met with a cowherd, to whom the Wolf had given
itie charge of her sheep, and with whom tin- di ore a bargain for getting them back, tails and al1. When the h'ld accomplished thta she returned hone
sfith them, where, assisted by some, friendly thepherdestes, the contrived to tack each of the tails of htr poor sheep in its plane atjuin. Iter totter,
Colin, a vouna shepherd, undertook to watch heflockall night, as Bo-peep was tired and wdnted to jo to bed.
The sheep being all carefully put
iMo the fold and watched by Colin, Bo-peep prepared to retire for the night : but when she had laid down, the wicked Wolf afipearedtocarry her
off by force—dragged her out nf hnl, mid', >, ilk the aid of his cmnpaniont, conquered Colin ; notwithstanding Bo.petp'i favorite black Ram, amf
htr dog, Lion, came to defend ihtsii mistress. In this exliemity she called upon her godmother to help her, mho immediately appeared in all her
fairy glory; changed Colin mlo Harleqinc Bopeep into Columbine, the wicked Wo'f into Pantaloon, and kit Cowherd into Clown. She then told
Bo-peep, that if, after twelve months, the nonld correct, herself of going to sleep m the day '.me, she would consent to her warrtage with Colin. It it
needless to add LtttliBo-peep did comet herself, vim married to Colin, and ujXerward* hveit like the. othtr shephn deues—as happy as the dayt
Were long.

T H S T R U E i l l STORY O F LIT I L B BO-PEEP.
COMPRISING

T H E INCIDENTS O F T H E P A N T O M I t l E .

godmother, who oat
a Fairy
with Bo-peep and bet* rejected by her, • ol of revenge, resolved to tlial her sheep, cut afi their tails, and hang them up o* a tree to dry.
Bo-peep,
as u-ual, having fallen asleep, rendend the dealing her flock a very easy matter for the Wolf and hit companions
Whi'c she mat sleeping, her
godmother shoved, to her, in a dream, the lonseqnenees of laziness ; and then there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesses mho were
living and playing and dancing in a grim if laburnums, and were happy as the days mere long, because in their time they had a«t er been idle. When
Bo-peep woke out of this dream, the fi.vn i her sheep had been taken away, so she set out determined for to find them ; when going along what should
she see, hut thctatls of alt l*r poor sheep longing up, side by side, on a tree to dry f She then met mith a cowherd, to whom the Wolf had given
the charge of her theep, and with whom the drove a bargain for getting them bach, tails and at'. When the had accomplished this she returned horn*
with them, where, assisted by some friendly shepherdesses, she contrived to tack each of the tails of her poor sheen in its plaoe again. Her lover;
Colin, a younq shepherd, undertook to milch the flock all night, as Bo-peep was tired and wanted to go to bed. The sheep being all carefully put
into the fold and watched by Colin, Bo-pt /• prepared to ret.re for the night; but when site had laid down, the wicked Wolf appeared to carry her
off by force—dragged her out of bed, and. * ith the aid of his companions, conquered Colin; notwithstanding Bo-peep's favorite black Ram, ami
her clog, Lion, came to defend their mistress. In this extremity, she called upon her godmother to help her, mho immediately appeared in all her
fairy glory; changed Colin into thrkquih, finperp into Columbine, the wicked Wolf into I'antalom, and its Cowherd into Clown. She then told
Bo-peep, that ifsOfler twelve months, sh< TIOHM correct herself of going to sleep in the dau time, she would oanstnt to her marriage with Colin. It it
neediest to add Little Bo-peep did correct Inrself, wa« married to Colin, and afterwards lived like the other shepherdesses—as happy as the dayt
dayt

were long.

THE TRUE HISTORY OF LIT!LB BO-PEEP.
COMPRISING

T H E INCIDENTS O F T H E PANTOMIME.

Ltftle lio-petp vias a pretty Shtpherdess, ret'niing m iked beautiful plum called Arcadia.
She was a very good g-'V, but had onr fault. and
that was, she mould often fall asleip in the day tai, when she emif)ts to have been tending her sheep. Her godmother, who was a Fairy, was ver-y
angry with her, end fried to cornet her, hut in rain : till erne day a Waif, nrho lived in a tavern near thu beautiful plact, having fallen in loveWith Bo-peep and been rejected by her, < vi of revenge, resolved to iteal her sheep, cut ->/f their tails, and hang them up oa a tree to dry.
Bo-peep,
as H.ual, having fallen asleep, render/ d the stealing her flock a vcrti easy matter for the Wolf and hie companion*.
Whi'e she mas sleeping, her
godmother showed to her, in a dream, the consequents of laziness : and then there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesses alto were
living and playing and dancing in a grove of bibtirnvns, and were happy as the dans reere long, because in their time they had net er been idle. When
Bo-peep tcohe out of this dream, she found her sheep had lieen taken away, so she set out determined for to find them ; when going along what should
she see, but the tails of all her poor sheep hanging up, side bu side, cm a tree to dry ! She then met with a cowherd, to whom the Wolf had given
the charge of her sheep, and with whom she i m n a bargain for getting them buck, tails and ttl. When site hod accomplished ihist she returned horn*
With them, re here, assisted bu some friendln shepherdssses, she contrived to tack each of the tails of her poor jlteafin its ptuae a(,ain. Iter timer,
Colin, a yosinj shepherd, undertook to zeoteh the Hock all night, as fta-ftrep was tired and .-MM to </o to bid.
The sheep bein , all carefully put
into the fold and watched by Colin, Bo-pei /> prepared to retire for the night : but when she hod laid down, the wicked Wolf appeared to carry her
off by force—dragged her out of bed, end, Kith the aid of his companions, conquered Colin ; nolwii\alanding Bo-peep'^ favorite black Ram, and
her'tog, Lfo», came lo defend their mistress, m this extremity she culled upon her godmother to help her, who immediately appeared in all her
fairy glory ; changed Colin into Harlequin, fiopeep into O Ivmbinc, the wicked Wolf into Pantaloon, and li» Cowherd into Clown. She. th»n told
Bo-peep, that if, after twelve months, the np"'d correct herself of going to s'eep in the day lime, she would consent lo her narriiq- with Colin. It is
needless to a-dd Little Bo-peep did correct htrteif, WHS ruurried to Calin, and afterwards lived like the other shepherdesses—as happy as the days
Were long.

, Little Bo-pecw was a pretty Bmrphenttss. resitting in dial beautiful pluee culled Arcadia.
She was a very goad girl, but had one fault: and
that was, she would often fdVosleip in ihr day time, when she ought to hare been leading her sheep. Her godmother, who teas a fain/, mat very
emgry Kith her, und tried to correct her. but w tain : till on« day a Waif, trho lived in a cavern near this beautiful place, having fallen in love
with Bo-peep and been rejected by her, • vt of revenge, resolved to steal her sheep, mil if their tails, and hang them np on n tree to dry.
Bo-peep,
as usuot, having fal'en asleep, rendend the stealing her fiocli a very easy matter far the H olf and his companions
While she tras sleeping, her
godmother showed to her, in a -ream. Ihr consequences af laziness : and then tliere appeared to her i group of beautiful Shepherdesses mhn were
Rring and playing and dancing in ayrovt of laburnums, and were happy as the days rrere. long, because in their time thet/ had net er keen idle. When
Bo-peep woke out of this dream, she found her sheep had been taken away, to she set out determined fir to find them : when going along what should
sh* see, but the tails af all her poor shati lumping up, side by side, cm a ire* to dry .' "She I hen met with a cowherd, to whom the Waif had given
the ehargtofhtr
sheep, and with whom tin- drove a bargain for gelling them bach, tails and alt. When the had accomplished this she returned homr
with them, Kherc, assisted by some friend!" tktpherdims, she contrived to tack each of the tails of her poor shelf t» its plan* again. Iter iorert
Colin, a uoHnj shepherd, nndcitooh to tttrceh ihe flock nil night, as Bo-peep was tired nnd ttanted to go to bed. The sheep being all Carefully put
into the fold and watched by Colin, Bo-ptsp prepared to retire for the night; but when she had laid down, the wicked Wolf appeared to harry her
off by force—-dragged her out of bed, ">,</. >e.ith Ihe aid of his crmpaniene, conquered Colin ; notwithstanding Bo-peep's favorite black Bam', and
her dog, Lion, came to defend their mistresf. hi this etlremity. she called tipon her godmother to help her, trho immediately appeared in all her
fairy glory; changed Cohn into Harlequin, Baptcp into Columbine, the wicked Wolf into Pantaloon, and Us Cowherd into Clown. She then laid
Bo-peep, that if, after twelve months, eke n o»ld, correct herself of going te sleep in the day lime, she would consent to her marriage urith Colin. It it
needless to add Ltttle Bo-peip di<i cvrifi t herself, van married to Colin, and afterwards lived like the other shepherdesses—-as happy as the day*

veere long.

T H E TRUiTlflSTORY OF LIT*LB BO-PEEP.
PANTOMIME.

FAMILY CARRIAGE.

a / ittlc Bo'pecp wo* a pretty Shtphrv't •">. residing in lhaJ beautiful plac* railed Arcadia.
She was a vcrtf yood girt, but had one fauH : and
thai was she mould often fall osleip "• 'A* dent ' " " f , when th* ovyht to have been tei ding her theep. Her godmothrr, who was a Faint wot very
ovarii v'ith htr and tried to correct I • •• hut i» " . . a •' till —« day a Waif, trho lived in a cavern near this beautiful placr, having fallen in love
rnfft Bo-peep irhtt been rejected on ter, •' of revenge, resolved lotteal her sheep, rut iff their tails, and hang them xp on a tree to drg.
Ho-peep,
a» \uiial licvivq fallen aslr i , r'tirf, . H '•"• sltaHug her flock n very MM! matter for tht Wolf tad hit companions
Whi'e site mas sleeping, her
aodniothlr showed to her in a dream, lite i •-• r/iinxr.i uf laziness ; and Men there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesses mho were
thina and planing and dancing in agnve <>j laburnums, and were happy as the dags tcere long, beeause in their time they had net er been idle. When
Bo-vecv wohc out of this dream, she found her sh'ep had been taken atony, so she. set out determined for to find them ; when going along what should
the see but the tails of all her poor sheep ' auying up, side by side, on a tree to dry .' $he then met mith a oowherd, to whom the Wolf had given
the charge of her theep, and ivith whom the drove a horgain for getting them back, tails and al'. When the had accomplished this she returned home
with them where aisi'ted by some fr•<«'.'''' sliephetdestes, she contrived to lock each of the tails of her - . o r sheep in its plmoe again. II'er lover,
Colin a youni shepheril, undertook It Oatek the flock alt niyht, as Bo-peep was tired and wonted to go to bed. The sheep being alt carefully put
mto the fold and watched by CM.*, Bo-ptep prepared to retire fur the night; but when she had laid down, the wicked Wolf appeared to Carry her
off by force—dragged her out of bed, ond. n>th the aid of his companions, conquered Colin : notwithstanding Bo-peep's favorite black Ram, and
her dog 1-ion come to defend thiir tnitrreu.
In this extremity she called upon Iter yodmolhtr to help her, tvho immediately appeared in all her
fairv glory; changed Colin into Ifarh <t''"i. Boptep into d.lumbine, the wicked Wolf into Pantaloon, and its Cowherd into Clown. She tlun told
Bo-vetp that if after twelve months, iff " »»W correct herself of going to sleep in the day time, she would consent to her marriage with Colin. It ,«
needless to add 'l.ittle Bo-peep did <mif hfrttlf, was married to Colin, and afterwords livid like the other shepherdesses—as happy as the days

f 1,title fla-peepwas a pretty Shfpherdess, residing m that beaatifnl place called Arcadia, She was a very goad girl, bat had out /.tt.'i. and"that was, the mould often fall asleep in the day time, when the ought to have been tending her theep. Her godmother, who teas a Fairn, urns verp
tvngsy Kith htr, t'tid tried to correct her, ln>t iv rain ; till one day a Waif, reho lived m a eitcrn near this beautiful place, having fallen in love
with Bo-peep and been rejected by her, int of reren^e, resohrd to ileal her sheep, tart off their t<iih, mid hang them up on a tret to dry. Ho-peep,
as vival, having fallen asleep, rendered the stealing her fiocft a very easy matter for the Wolf and hit companime. While the mat sleeping, her
godmother 'Itemed to her, in a dream, the MSMM-at. „f fa-ixess: and then there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesses' ofto wtrer
'firing and playing mid dancing tn a grave of lutivrnnw t, and were happy as the days were '«'g, bttause. in their time they had act er been idle. Whe.n
'•Ho-fteep wote i ill of this dream, she found Iter simp hail been taken away, so she set out determined for to find them : u>hen going along what should?
the see, but the tails of all her poor sheep banging »p. side by side, on a tre* to dry ! She then met with a eewherd, to wham the Wolf had give*
the charge of her sheep, and with whom the drove a bargain for getting them bach, tails and all. When she had accomplished this she returned horn*
tcith them, where, assisted by some friendly shepherdesses, she contrived to tack each of the tails of her poor sheep in its plaoe again. Her lover,
CoHn, a yatma shepherd, unekrtaoh to itateh the flock all night, as Uo-peep was tired and uanted to go to bed.
The sheep being all carefully put
tnto the fold and icatched hy Ca/tn, Bo-}-eq> prepared la retire for the night; bat trhen site hod laid down, the wicked Wolf appeared to carry her
off by force—dragged her met of bed, and, nilh the aid of his companion., conquered Colin ; notwithstanding Bo-peep's• favorite black Bam, and
tier clog, Lion, came to defend their mistress, hi this extremity she called upon her fodmolhtr to help her, tvko immediately appended, in all her
fairy glory, changed Colin mto Ifarltqmv, B'peep i,,t0 Columbine, the nicked Wolf into Pantaloon, and Us Cowherd into Clown. She thtn told
Bo-peep, that if, after tacks months, the teould correct herself of going to sleep in the day time, she would consent to her marriage with Colin. It it
Heedless to add Little Bo-peep did corn-it1 herself, «»i married to Coiin, arid afterwards lived like the other shepherdesses—«•» happy as the dam, "
West long.

Little Bo-pccp was a pretty Shtpherdess, residing in that beaiitifvl place railed Arcadia.
She was a very good girl, but had one fault: and
that was, she mould often fall atletp in the day time, when she ought ft. have been tending her sheep. Her godmother, who OM . a Fairy, was very
attain with far. end tried to cornet her, hut pi fain ; till one dug a Waif, sthn lived in a (avern near this beautiful place, having fallen in lore
with Bo-peep and been rejected by her, tnt of revenge, resolved tustia' her sheep, cat ?Jf their tails, and hang them up on a tree to dry.
Bo-pccp>
as uiual, having fallen asleep, rendered the stealing her fort- a very easy matter for thi Wolf and his companions.
While she. j»a« sleeping, her
godmother ihovrd to her, in a dream, the eaMequmett of laziness : arid then there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesses mho were
living end) laying and divtring in a gr re nl lulmrntun ••, and were happy as the days were long, because in their lime they had net er been idle. Whem
Bo-peep nohe out of this dream, she fonnd her sheep had heen taken away, so she set onl determined for to find them : when going along u>hat should
she see, but the. tails of alt her poer sltctp liavgiug vp, side by side, on a tree to dry .' She then met reith a cawlierd, te wham the Wolf had give*
the charge of her sheep, and with whom she drove a bargain for getting them back, fails and nit. When she had aecompliihed this she returned horn*
teith them, tekere, assisted by some friendly shepherdesses, she contrived to tark each of the tails of her poor sheep in its plane again. Her loverj
Colin, a yovn'f shepherd, undertook to —den lite flock all night, as Re-peep ra tired and wanted to go to bed. The sheep being all Carefully put
tnto the fold and watched by Colin, lin-feip prepared to retire for the night, but whin she had laid down, the wicked Wolf appeared to carry her
of by J'arce— dragged her out of bed, nnd. ndh the aid of his companions, conquered Colin; notwithstanding Bo-peep's favorite black Ram, and
her dog, Lien, crime to defend their mistress, h this extri ntity. she called tipon her godmother to help her, who immitdiatelti appeared in ail her
fairy glory; changed C'din into HaYlefuin, Ihpap into Cidvmbinc, the wicked Wolf into Pantaloon, and Us Cowherd into Clown. She then told
Bo-peep, that if, after twelve months, she n mid correct herself of goinq to sleep in the day lime, slie would consent to her wantage with Colin, If «.
needless to add Little Bo-peep did correct lifrsrlf, WHS married to Colin, and afterwards lived like the other shrpherde*ses~tn
happy as the days
were long.

THE

T R U E HISTORY O P L I T T L E BO-PEEP.
COMPRISING

T H E INCIDENTS O F T H E PANTOMIME.

Little Bo.pecp <«-•» 1 pretty Shepherdess, residing in that beautiful place called Arcadia. She was a very good girl, but had one fault. and
that wm, she rronld often fall asleep in the day time, when she ought to hate been tending her sheep. Her godmother, who Teas a Fairif, teas very
avgtv with htr, i lid tried to comet her, rut in tain : till one day a Waif, rcho lived tn a cavern near this beautiful place, having fallen«'» tot*
•with Bo-peep and been rejected by her, < vt of revenge, resolved to steal her sheep, cut off their tails, and hang them up on a tree to dry. Bo-peep,
as usual, harinij fallen asleep, rendered the stealing her flock a very easy matter for the Wolf and his companions. While she mas sleeping, her
•gsdmollur showed to her, »'B a dream, the consequences of laziness : and then there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesses who were
lirriKiandflayiVfi and dancing in a grove of laburnums, and were happy as the days mere long, because in their lime they Had net er been idle. When
JHi>-peep woke out of this dreem, she found her sheep had been taken away, so she set out determined fat to find them; when going along what should
she ite, but the tails of all htr poor sheep hanging up, side by side, on a tree to dry ! She then met mith a cowherd, to whom the Wolf had given
the charge of her sheep, and with whom she drove a bargain for getting them 6oe.i," tails and all. When the had accomplished this she returned Kama
mith them, where, assisted by some friendly shepherdesses, she contrived to tack each of the tails of her poor sheep in its ptaoe again. Her lover,
Colin, a yauna shepherd^ undertook to teateh the flock all night, as Bo-peep was tired and wanted to go to bed.
The sheep being all carefully put

THE TRUW HISTORY OP LITTLE HO-PEEP.

r r i a w for the F-aest Babies—tittle I.ov.w-.-Clown*s Baby, Pantaloon'. Baby, and Harlequin's Baby—Bow amongst the Mother*,

C O M P R I S I N G T H E .BMBBBuB
OF T H E PANTOMIME,
.Little Bo-peep wot a pretty Shepkerdest, residing in that beautiful place cawed Arcadia,
She was a very good girl, but
had one/kilt
{ and that was, ehe would often fall asleep in the day time, when ike ought to have been tending her e'heep.
Her godmother, who was a Fairy, woe very angry with her, and tried to correct her, but in vain; till one day a Wolf, who
lived in a cavern near this beautiful place, having fallen in lete with Bo-peep and been rejected by her, out of revenge, retohed to steal her sheep, cut off' their tails, and hang them up on a tree to dry. Bo-peep, as usual, hating fallen asleep
rendered the stealing her flock a very easy matter for the Wolf and his companions.
While she was sleeping, her godmother
ohowed to her, in a dream, the consequences of laziness ; and then there appeared to her a group of beautiful
Shepherdesses
teho were living and playing and dancing in a grove of laburnums, and were happy as the days were long, because in their
time they had never been idle.
WhenBo-peep
woke out of this dream, she found her sheep had been taken away, so ehe set
out, determined for to find them ,• when going along what should she see, but the tails of all her poor eheep hanging up, side
by side, on a tree to dry ! She then met with a cowherd, to whom the Wolf had given the charge of her sheep, and with
whom she drove a bargain for getting them bach, tails and all. When she had accomplished this ehe returned home, where,
assisted by some friendly shepherdesses, she contrived to tack each of the tails of her poor sheep in its place again. Her
lover, Colin, a young shepherd, undertook to watch the flock all night, as Bo-peep was tired ana wanted to go to bed. The
sheep being all carefully put into the fold and watched by Colin, Bo-peep prepared to retire for the night; but when ehe had
laid down, the wicked Wolf appeared to carry her offby force—dragged
her out of bed, and,with the aid of his
companions,
eoneuered Colin ; notwithstanding
Bo-peep's favorite black Ram, and her dog, Lion, came to defend their mistress.
In this
extremity, she called upon her godmother to help Iter, who immediately appeared in all her fairy glory ; changed Colin into

other Shepherdesses—as

THE TRUE HISTORY OF LITTLE BO-PEEP.

Exterioi of Lady Frolic's H o u s e .

C O M P R I S I N G -THE I N C I D E N T S O F T H E P A N T O M I M H ,
Ltttle Bo-peep teat a pretty Shepherdess, residing in that beautiful place called Arcadia.
She was a very good girl, but
had one fault;
and that teas, she would often fall asleep in the day time, when she ought to have been tending her sheep.
Her godmother, who teat a Fairy, teas very angry with her, and tried to correct hor, but in vain; till one day a Wolf, who
lived i . a Cavern near this beautiful place, having fallen in lore with Bo-peep and been rejected by her, out of revenge, resolved to steal her sheep, cut off" their tails, and hang them up on a tree to dry. Bo-peep, as usual, hating fallen asleep,
rendered the stealing her flock a very easy matter for the Wolf and hit companions,
While she teas sleeping, her godmother
showed to her, in a dream, the consequences of laziness ; and then there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesses
who Vert living and playing and dancing in a grove of laburnums, and were happy as the days were long, because in their
time they had never been idle. WhenBo-peep woke out of this dream, the found her sheep had been taken away, so the set
tut, determined for to find them ; when going along what should she see, but the tails of all her poor sheep hanging up, tide
iy tide, on a tree to dry I She then met with a cowherd, to whom the Wolf had given the charge of her sheep, and with
whom the drove a bargain for getting them back, tails and all. When she had accomplished this the returned home, where,
assisted by tome friendly shepherdesses, she contrived to tack each of the tails of her poor sheep in its place again. Her
lover, Colin, a young shepherd, undertook to watch the flock mil night, at Bo-peep was tired and wanted to go to bed. The
sheep being all carefully put into the fold and watched by Colin, Bo-peep prepared to retire for the nigh'; but when the smut
laid down, the wicked Wolf appeared to carry her off by force—dragged her out of bed, and, with the aid of his companions,
toneuered Colin ; notwithstanding Bo-peep''if "avortte black Ram, and her dog, Lion, came to defend their mistress. In this
extremity, the called upon her godmother to help her, who immediately appeared in alt her fairy glory 1 changed Colin into
Harlequin, Bo-peep into Columbine, the wicked Wolf into Pantaloon, and his Cowherd into Clown. She then told Bo-peep,
that if, after twelve months, she would currect herself of going to sleep in the day time, she would consent to her marriage
with Colin, It is needless to add Little Bo-peep did correct herttlf, was married to Colin, and afterwards lived tike the
Other Shepherdesses—as happy as the days were long.

HARLEQUIN'S

THE TRUE HISTORY OF LIITLf! BO-PEEP.
COMPRISING T H E INCIDENTS O FT H E PANTOMIME.
Little Bo-peep was a pretty Shepherdess, residing in that beautiful place called Arcadia.
She wan a very good girl, but
had one favlt;
and that wax, she would often fall asleep in the dny time, when she ought to have been tending her sheep.
Her godmother, who was a Fairy, was very angry with her, and tried to correct her, but in rain; till one day a Wolf, who
lived in a cavern near this beautiful place, hating fallen in lore with Bo-peep and been njec/ed by her, out of revenge, resolved to steal her sheep, cut off their laili, and hang them up on a tree to dry. Bo-peep, as usual, having fallen
athn,
rendered the stealing herflock a very easy matter for the Wolf and his companions,
While she was sleeping, her godmother
showed to her, in a dream, the consequences of laziness; ar.d then there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesses
who were living and playing and dancing in a grove of laburnums, and were happy as the days were long, because m their
time they had never been idle. WhevBo-peep woke out of this dream, she found her sheep had been taken away, so she sit
out, determined for to find them ; when going along what should she see, but the tails of ah her poor sheep hanging up, side
by side, m a tree to dry ! She then met with a cowherd, to ivhom the Wolf had given the charge of her sheep, and with
whom she drove a bargain for getting them back, tails and all. When she had accompliihed this the returned home, where,
assisted by some friendly shepherdesses, she centrived to tack each of the tails of her poor sheep in its place again. Her
lever, Colin, a young shepherd, undertook to watch the flock all night, as Bo-peep teas tired and wanted to go to bed. The
$htev being all carefully put into the fold and watched by CoWn, Bo-peep prepared to retire for the night; but when she had
laid down, the wicked Wolf appeared to carry her off by force—dragged her out of bed, and, with the aid of his companion*,
eonquered Colin ; notwithstanding Bo-peep's favorite black Ram, and her dog, Lion, came to defend their mistress. In this
extremity, she called vpon her godmother to help her, who immediately appeared in all her fairy glory ; changed Colin into
Harlequin, Bo-peep into Columbine, the wicked Wolf into Pantaloon, and his Cowherd into Clown. She then told Bo-peep.
that if, after twelve months, she would correct herself of going to sleep in the day time, she would consent to her marriage
with Colin, It is needless to add Little Bo-peep did correct herself, was married to Colin, and afterwards lived like the
other Shepherdesses—as happy as the days were long.

All hung on a tree to dry.

She found them indeed, but it made her heart bleed,
For they'd left all their tails behind them.

Or, H A R L E Q U I N AND T H E

GIRL WHO LOST HEB SHEEP.
THE TRUE HISTORY OF LITTLE HO-PEEP.
COMPRISING T H E INCIDENTS O F T H E PANTOMIME.
Little Bo-peep was a pretty Shepherdess, residing in that beautiful place called Arcadia.
She was a very good girl, but
had one fault;
and that teas, she would often fall asleep in the day time, when she ought to have been tending her sheep.
Her godmother, who was a Fairy, was very angry with her, and tried to correct her, but in vain; till one day a Wolf, who
lived in a cavern near this beautiful place, having fallen in love with Bo-peep and been rejected by her, out of revenge, resolved to steal her sheep, cut off their tails, and hang them up on a tree to dry. Bo-peep, us usual, hating fallen asleep,
rendered the stealing her flock a very easy matter for the Wolf and his companions.
While she was sleeping, her godmother
showed to her, in a dream, the consequences of laziness; and then there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesses
who were living and playing and dancing in a grove of laburnums, and were happy as the days were long, because in their
time they had never been idle.
WhenBo-peep woke out of this dream, she found her sheep had been taken away, so she set
out, determined for to find them ; when going along what should she see, but the tail* of all her poor sheep hanging up, tide
by side, on a tree to dry ! She then met with a cowherd, to whom the Wolf had given the charge of Tier sheep, and with
whom she drove a bargain for getting them back, tails and all. When she had accomplished this she returned home, where,
assisted by some friendly shepherdesses, she contrived to tack each of the tail* of her poor sheen in it* place again. Her
lover, Colin, a young shepherd, undertook to watch the flock all tight, as Bo-peep teas tired and wanted to go to bed. The
sheep being all carefully put into the fold and watched by Colin, Bo-peep prepared to retire for the night,' but when the had
laid down, the wicked Wolf appeared to carry htr off by force—dragged her out of bed, and, with the aid of his companions,
conquered Colin; notwithstanding Bo-peep11 favorite black Ram, and her dog, Lion, came to defend their mistress. In this
extremity, she called Upon her godmother to help her, who immediately appeared in all her fairy glory ; changed Colin into
Harlequin, Bo-peep into Columbine, the wicked Wolf into Pantaloon, and his Cowherd into Cloten. She then told Bo-peep,
that if, after twelve months, she would correct herself of going to sleep in the day time, she would consent to her marriage
with Colin, It is needless to add Little Bo-peep did correct herself, was married to Colin, and afterwards lived like the
other Shepherdesses—as happy as the days were long.

GIRL WHO LOST HER SHEEP.
THE TRUE HISTORY OF LITTLE BO-PDEP.
COMPRISING. T H E INCIDENTS O F T B E FANTOBIIME.
"• Little Bo-peep wat a pretty Shepherdess, residing in that beautiful place called Arcadia,
She was a very good girl, but
Had one fault;
and that was, the would often foil asleep in the day time, when ike ought to have been tending her sheep.
tier godmothtr, who was a Fairy, was very angry uith her, and tried to correct her, but in vain; till one day a Wolf, who
liotd in a cavern near thit beautiful place, hai trig fallen in fate with Bo-peep and been rejected by her, out of revenge, retained to steal her sheep, cut off" their tails, and hang them up on a tree to dry. Bo-peep, as usual, hating fallen adeep,
rendered the stealing herflock a very easy matter for the Wolf and his companions,
While she was sleeping, her godmother
showed to her, in a dream, the consequences of laziness; and then there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesses
who Were living and playing and dancing in a grove of laburnums, and were happy as the days were long, because in their
time they had never been idle. WhenBo-peep woke out of this dream, the found her sheep had been taken away, to the let
ui, determined for to find them f when going along what should she see but the tail* of all her poor sheep hanging up, tide
y ttde, on a tree to dry ! She then met with a cowherd, to tehom the Wolf had given the charge of her sheep, and with
Khom she drove a bargain for getting them back, tails and all. When she had accomplished this the returned home, where,
assisted by tome friendly shepherdesses, she contrived to tack each of the tails of her poor theep in its place again.
Iter
lover, Colin, a young shepherd, undertook to watch the flock all night, as Bo-peep was tired and wanted to go to bed. The
sheep being all carefully put int••> the fold and watched by Colin, Bo-peep prepared to retire for the nigh'; but when the had
fata down, the wicked Wolf appeared to carry Iter off by force—d> agged her out of bed, and, with the aid of his companions,
tonquered Colin ; notwithstanding Bo-peep't favorite black Ram, and her dog, Lion, came to defend their mistress. In this
extremity, the called upon her godmother to help her, who immediately appeared in all her fairy glory ; changed Colin into
Harlequin, Bo-peep into Columbine, the wicked Wolf into Pantaloon, and h's Cowherd into Clown. She then told Bo-peep,
that if, after twehe months, she would correct herself of going to sleep in the day time, she would consent to her marriage
with Colin, It it needless to add Little Bo-peep did correct herself, was married to Colin, and afterwards lived like the
other Shepherdesses—as happy as the days were long.

DETERMINATION

A N D DISCOVERY,

It happened one day, ae Bo-peep did stray,
Into a meadow hard by,
There she espy'd, their tails side by tide,
All hung on a tree to dry.

Then up the took her little crook,
Determined for to find them ;
She found them indeed, but it made her heart bleed,
For they'd left all their tails behind them.

DISCOVERY.

OF LITTLE BO-PEEP.
L I T T L E
R O-P E E P'S
R E M E D Y .

OF THE PANTOMIME!
3rd.

A N D

It happened one day, as Bo-peep did stray,
into a meadow hard by,
There she espy'd, their tails side by side,
All hung on a tree to dry.

INTERIOR i COTTAGE' SHEBPFOLD

MORNING PERFORMANCE
FEBRUARY

FEN.

D E T E R M I N A T I O N

Then tip she look her little crook,
Determined for to find them ;
She found them indeed, but it made her heart bleed,
For they'd left all their tails behind them.

She found them indeed, but it made her heart bleed,
tar they'd left all their taile behind them.

Into a meadow hard by,
There she espy'd, their tails side by side,
All hung en a tree to dry.

GIRL WHO LOST HER SHEEP.
THE TRUE HISTORY OF LITTLE BO-PEEP.
C O M F R I S m a T H E IWCIDEH ' J . O F T H E P A S T O M I M B .
LiitI* Bo-peep was a pretty Shepherded, residing in that beautiful place called Arcadia.
She vol a very good girl but
had en* fault;
and that was, the mould often fall atletp in the day time, when the ought to have been lending htr sheept
Her godmother, who was a Fairy, teat very angry with her, and tried to correct her, but in vain; till one day a Wolf, wh*
lived tn a cavern near this beautiful place, having fallen in lore with Bo-peep and been rejected by her, out of revenge, r # .
solved to steal her sheep, cut off their tails, and hang them up on a tree to dry. Bo-peep, as usual, hating fallen
atleep,
rendered the stealing her flock a very easy matter for the Wolf and his companions* While she was sleeping, her godmother
showed te her, in a dream, the consequences of laziness ; and then there appeared to her a group of beautiful Shepherdesset
who were living and playing and dancing in a grove of laburnume, and were happy as the days were long, because in their
time they had never been idle. WhenBo-peep woke out of this dream, she found her sheep had been taken away, so she eel
out, determined for te find them ; when going along what should she see. but the tails of ah her poor sheep hanging up, tide
by side, on a tree to dry ! She then met with a cowherd, to whom the Wolf had given the charge of her sheep, and with
•whom she drove a bargain for getting them back, tails and all. When she had accomplished this she returned home, where,
assisted by some friendly shepherdesses, she contrived to tack each of the taile of her poor theep j.t »V# place again. Her
lover, Colin, a young shepherd, undertook to watch the ftoek all night, as Bo-peep was tired and wanted to go to bed. The
Iheep being all carefully put into the fold and watched by Colin, Bo-peep prepared te retire for the night; but when ehe had
laid down, the wicked Wolf appeared to carry htr off by force—dragged her em of bed, and, with the aid of his companions,
toneuered Colin; notwithstanding Bo-peep's favorite black Ram, and her dog, IAon, earns te) defend their mistress.
In this
extremity, she called upon her godmother to help her, who immediately appeared in all her fairy glory i changed Cvlin into
Harlequtn, Bo-peep into Columbine, the wicked Wolf into Pantaloon, and his Cowherd into Clown. She then told Bo-peep,
that if, after twelve months, she would correct herself of going to sleep in the day time, she would eonsent to her marriage
with Colin, It is needless to add Little Bo-peep did correct herself, wa« married to Colin, and afterwards lived like the
other Shepherdesses—a* happy as the days were long.

A N D DISCOVERY.
It happened one day, as Bo peep did stray,
Into a meadow hard by,
Thtre she etpijd, their tails side by side,
All hung on a tree to dry.

Determined for to find them t
She found <*em indeed, but it made her heart bleed,
For they'd left all their tail* behind them.
